thread.title_full: Bucks' Henson says he was racially profiled at jewelry store - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Bucks' Henson says he was racially profiled at jewelry store
text:
Nathaniel S. Butler/NBAE/Getty Images John Henson (#31) of the Milwaukee Bucks took to Instagram to say he was the victim of racial profiling at an upscale jewelry store in Milwaukee. NBA player John Henson is blowing the whistle on a "degrading" experience at a Milwaukee-area jewelry store Monday.
The Milwaukee Bucks power forward took to Instagram and said he was the victim of racial profiling at upscale bauble broker Schwanke-Kasten in Whitefish Bay, just north of the largest city in Wisconsin.
"They locked the door and told me to go away. After I rang the doorbell twice everyone went to the back. No answered the door or told me what was going on," Henson, who is black, wrote in the exasperated social media post.
John Henson/via Instagram Henson said cops were called on him at Schwanke-Kasten in the Whitefish Bay area of Milwaukee.
"This was followed by two police cars pulling up and parking across the street and watching me for 5 minutes," he wrote, explaining that he assumed the cops were called by the store.
He said two officers approached and questioned him about what he was doing outside the shop and the dealer vehicle he was driving.
Henson, 24, said the car is part of an endorsement deal he has with Kunes Country Chevrolet.
"I told them I was just trying to look at a watch. (The police officer) then had to go in the back and tell them to come out it was safe but this is after they ran my plates and I overheard them talking about doing more of a background check on the car," he wrote.
"The employees finally came out of the back and proceeded to conduct business like they previously were as we walked up," he told his 51,000 Instagram followers.
He called the incident one of the worst experiences with racial prejudice he's ever experienced.
Gary Dineen/NBAE/Getty Images NBA player John Henson described a "degrading" experience at a Milwaukee jewelry store.
"I wouldn't wish this on anyone. This store needs to be called out and that's what I'm doing. You have no right to profile someone because of their race and nationality and this incident needs to be brought to light and I urge anyone who ever is thinking of shopping here reads this and doesn't bring any business to this discriminatory place," he said.
A message left with Schwanke-Kasten was not immediately returned to the Daily News.
Henson, who stands 6 feet 11 inches tall, played for the University of North Carolina and was drafted by the Bucks in the first round in 2012.
He recently signed a four-year extension with Milwaukee.
His Instagram post quickly scored more than a thousand likes and more than 150 comments from fans and supporters.
